update.description:
Component type names were removed on pull request #188 because they were causing esoteric test failures on Homebrew. As that PR evolved however, I believe a few changes were made which fixed that issue, along with others.

So this PR brings the names back and uses them in the debug message when a new component type is used, which is really helpful when debugging `SerializedState` messages (see pull request #184 for reference).

I also expect type names to be used by user-facing features like logging, where the user will be able to specify which components to log via the command line for example.
update.title: [Acropolis] Bring component type names back

content.raw:
Thanks for linking the issue, they do seem similar.

Now GCC is unhappy. I'll revert the unique name changes from this PR so the original typename stuff can be reviewed independently and open a new PR for uniqueness checks.
content.html:
Thanks for linking the issue, they do seem similar.

Now GCC is unhappy. I'll revert the unique name changes from this PR so the original typename stuff can be reviewed independently and open a new PR for uniqueness checks.

content.raw:
I might have mentioned this before, but this reminds me of a different clang issue I've seen in sdformat:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/202/bad_any_cast-after-element-getany-with
content.html:
I might have mentioned this before, but this reminds me of a different clang issue I've seen in sdformat:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/202/bad_any_cast-after-element-getany-with

content.raw:
Clang was not happy about enforcing unique names because it wasn't sharing the static variables across libraries, so whenever a new library that uses the component is loaded, it would try to register it again, fail, and the component would be ID-less and nameless for that plugin. I don't know why the same doesn't happen with GCC.

So now, what it's doing is:

* If the ID is already set (i.e. != 0) we don't set it again and silently return.
* Otherwise, set the ID anyway
* But if the maps have already been filled for that ID, we don't overwrite these entries.
* However, if the runtime name of the component is different from the previously registered one, we print an error. This will not prevent the user from trying to use one component as if it was the other, which will potentially cause crashes, but at least it makes the issue traceable.

I'm also unregistering components as their libraries are unloaded so they don't dangle around, but developers should think carefully about this when sharing custom components across libs.
	
50ac317
content.html:
Clang was not happy about enforcing unique names because it wasn't sharing the static variables across libraries, so whenever a new library that uses the component is loaded, it would try to register it again, fail, and the component would be ID-less and nameless for that plugin. I don't know why the same doesn't happen with GCC.

So now, what it's doing is:

  • If the ID is already set (i.e. != 0) we don't set it again and silently return.
  • Otherwise, set the ID anyway
  • But if the maps have already been filled for that ID, we don't overwrite these entries.
  • However, if the runtime name of the component is different from the previously registered one, we print an error. This will not prevent the user from trying to use one component as if it was the other, which will potentially cause crashes, but at least it makes the issue traceable.

I'm also unregistering components as their libraries are unloaded so they don't dangle around, but developers should think carefully about this when sharing custom components across libs.

50ac317

update.title: [Acropolis] Bring component type names back

content.raw:
Nice catch, I made some changes in 56acb9f to enforce ID and name uniqueness, and I had to fix a test which was taking advantage of the fact that the test and the plugin were registering the exact same type.

This has the potential of breaking downstream user code, but I think we should disallow it to prevent errors. If plugins want to share components, they should link against each other.
content.html:
Nice catch, I made some changes in 56acb9f to enforce ID and name uniqueness, and I had to fix a test which was taking advantage of the fact that the test and the plugin were registering the exact same type.

This has the potential of breaking downstream user code, but I think we should disallow it to prevent errors. If plugins want to share components, they should link against each other.

content.raw: We should check that `namesById` doesn't already have a matching `typeId` in the case that either a\) multiple components use the same typeName or b\) there is a hash collision \(unlikely\)

content.raw:
Yeah I understand it the same way as you do. But just to be safe, I removed the function because it wasn't being used anyway. I also made `idsToNames` static in the hope that the report comes back clean this time. `Factory` is a singleton, so it should be ok.

content.raw:
Although it’s reporting a failed ABI test, the description of the failure indicates that it’s okay.

> Call of any virtual method at **higher** position in this class or its subclasses may result in crash or incorrect behavior of applications.

I assume that `higher` means a higher index, but the new `BaseComponent::TypeName` symbol is at the highest index in the table, so nothing should be affected.
content.html:
Although it’s reporting a failed ABI test, the description of the failure indicates that it’s okay.

Call of any virtual method at higher position in this class or its subclasses may result in crash or incorrect behavior of applications.

I assume that higher means a higher index, but the new BaseComponent::TypeName symbol is at the highest index in the table, so nothing should be affected.

content.raw:
humm it's still [not happy](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/234/API_5fABI_20report/) though...

We can live without the `TypeName` function in Acropolis and just keep the `typeName` member and the `NameById` function. But even the `idsToNames` member is causing low severity issues.
content.html:
humm it's still not happy though...

I'm not sure if it being pure or not matters; I thought it was just adding a virtual function was the problem, but we'll see what the job says

are we ready to guarantee ABI stability for ign-gazebo?
